Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Designing An Information Savvy Society: Assessable Participatory Information Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the design of participatory systems to enable assessment of information quality and to encourage contributions. It does so by designing system interfaces that allow people to better see into processes of information production to better assess their products and, by extension, to identify valued forms of contribution. The project includes (1) construction of models of how people with different kinds and levels of expertise in information production understand and assess the quality of information in participatory environments and how these understandings intersect with patterns of participation; (2) creating experimental interfaces that support information assessment; (3) studying these interfaces in iterative deployments to develop a design framework and guidelines for assessable participatory information environments; and (4) validating this design framework through summative evaluation in a novel context. The project also includes the design and implementation of participatory information literacy education activities for students that encourage participation in public information production.

The results of this research will advance scientific understanding of information assessment habits among users of participatory media. The development of novel interfaces for well-known and familiar systems will provide design framework and guidelines that are accessible and extensible from both a scholarly and technical perspective.

The design framework and guidelines that result from this project will improve design and educational practice in an area of critical national importance, namely information literacy. Improving information literacy skills is important, as they affect citizens' ability to function in a technologically rich, free and democratic society and to make informed decisions about scientific, medical, educational and other issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the research team began by examining information assessment and creation practices. We wanted to better understand how online environments can be designed to help people 1. assess the quality of the information they find online, 2. share and produce information that is of high quality. These questions led to several interesting findings and, in some cases, created new research directions and questions.

We found that when people go online to find information on sites like Wikipedia (and even blogs and other kinds of sites) they pay attention to two features of the information they find: provenance, or where the information came from (were there sources cited? What were they, etc?) and stewardship, or how the information is taken care of (who makes sure it’s up to date, etc?). We developed and tested ideas based on these features to help inform the design of informational sites to help people assess the information they find there. These studies led to further collaborations with Wikimedia Foundation and findings about how information sources are cited and how citation in online environments differs from citation in the scientific literature.

As a part of our initial investigations, we became interested in the role of anonymous information producers—if people traditionally judge information in part based on who provides it and the reputation of the information provider (does the information come from an expert? From a reputable publisher, etc?), then we wanted to understand how can online environments account for the fact that many people who provide information online are anonymous or pseudonymous. We began to investigate the role of anonymous contributors in online environments. What we found is that many people remain anonymous when they are helping create information because they face serious privacy or safety risks. This anonymity study spawned an entirely new line of research that has been developed as a separate collaboration investigating the value of anonymity online.

Finally, our work on information sharing and production, and particularly our emphasis on anonymity, created a highly successful research thread on sharing information about difficult-to-disclose information like mental health issues, pregnancy loss, abuse, and other sensitive topics. Aside from simply creating information about these topics, which may involve seeking anonymity, we were  interested in when people share their own experiences and how they fund help. This research thread resulted in a new theory of online sensitive information sharing that we call “network level reciprocal disclosure,” as well as design guidelines for supporting those who wish to go online to find help for themselves and to provide help for others.
